nodes.bodyText: shouldn't this be either forCreate or forUpdate if the test is about verifying the document structure that is to be persisted as indicated in the JavaDoc?

The reason I didn't use one of those is that I wanted to test if every property of the DTO is serialised as expected. If I had used forCreate() or forUpdate() not all fields would be populated and the test code would be partially duplicated.
Maybe it would help if I put what I stated above into a comment?
FMPOV it would be more helpful to have separate test methods which test the DTO in the way(s) that it is supposed to be used by client code ...
DownstreamSenderFactory is deprecated. Can you please use the new client's ProtonBasedDownstreamSender instead?

nodes.bodyText:
Do you mind if I create an issue and do this after this PR, the JDBC PR and especially the integration tests are merged, so that I can test the migration more easily?
As this involves changing the AutoProvisioner this will not only affect the MongoDb registry but also the JDBC and File registry and would involve semi-manual re-testing on my machine for all of them.

nodes.bodyText: is this used anywhere in this test?

Yes in the line below:
when(downstreamSenderFactoryMock.connect()).thenReturn(Future.succeededFuture());

Sure, but why should downstreamSenderFactoryMock.connect() ever be invoked? I do not see any place where the created downstreamSenderFactoryMock is being used by or injected into any of the objects under test. Or am I mistaken?
Sorry - didn't see the wood before the trees. You're right that is obsolete.
is this used anywhere?
See #2360 (comment)
should this be related to the instant set in the DeviceStatus?
what about the updated on field? Shouldn't that contain the same instant as the created on field in this case?

should this be related to the instant set in the DeviceStatus?

No, actually the device status should be ignored.
I added a DeviceStatus object to the test since the properties of DeviceStatus partially have the same name as the properties in the DTO subclasses. Before adding the @JsonIgnore annotation to the deviceStatus property in DeviceDto they were accidentally serialised but the error was hard to spot since everything was still working but there was an additional, unwanted property being serialized.
To make sure this doesn't accidentally happen in future (e.g. when someone changes the Jackson annotation again), I added that to the test case as well.

what about the updated on field? Shouldn't that contain the same instant as the created on field in this case?

If the DTO was created by using forCreation() it can't have been updated yet which is why there is no update timestamp set. We could also set the same timestamp for created and updated but it is more cumbersome for someone viewing the entry to spot whether it has been updated at all yet (one needs to compare the created and updated timestamp for equality then).

No, actually the device status should be ignored.
I added a DeviceStatus object to the test since the properties of DeviceStatus partially have the same name as the properties in the DTO subclasses. Before adding the @JsonIgnore annotation to the deviceStatus property in DeviceDto they were accidentally serialised but the error was hard to spot since everything was still working but there was an additional, unwanted property being serialized.

That's a good idea 👍  IMHO we should make it explicit then and add corresponding assertions as well.
but this is supposed to be the same value as in the DeviceStatus, right? If so, we could also make it more explicit by comparing to DeviceStatus.isAutoProvisioned(). WDYT?
